Text: [Michael] Before I embarked on my journey to Japan,
to learn about the Cognitive Tradeoff hypothesis,
I first visited Dr. Terrence Deacon,
professor of neuroanthropology at UC Berkeley.
to learn about the hardware on which language had to be installed: the brain.
[Deacon] So, these are all preserved brains in formaldehyde.
You know what I love about this room?
One is that you've got a cabinet
full of giant buckets that just have your name on them,
and they don't look like they contain nice stuff.
But also this fridge-- "BIOHAZARD."
-That's not where you keep your lunch. -That's right.
-This is not a place where people get to eat. -Right.
This is just a human brain,
preserved and then wrapped up in Saran Wrap,
like a leftover.
You clearly didn't just grab this from someone.
No, that's right. Today human brains are highly protected,
and lots of paperwork is required.
They're available, but it takes a lot of careful tracking...
-Do you have to like report on, "Yep, I still have it. Hasn't been stolen..."  -Yep, exactly.
Who is it?
- I do know that this is from a male. -Okay.
I believe this is an 80-year-old,
but roughly in that range.
Let's move on to this brain.
So, this is a bonobo, close relative to chimpanzees.
No kidding. They look really similar.
In biological terms, humans are just another African ape.
In cognitive terms, we're like a whole other phylum of animals.
So, I mean, where are these physical differences that make us--
-Right. -I mean, maybe we're not that different, really.
So, in one respect, none of these brains
have parts that others lack, including the human brain.
There's no special part in the human brain
to do any of the things that make us special.
And that's, again, because of the incredibly conservative nature
of how brains have evolved.
Why don't I just pick one of the primate brains,
and the human brain, and we'll just compare different brains.
There's something that feels very strange about knowing
that this...belonged to a person.
I mean, the ape, it's very-- It's amazing how different that feels.
-I tell people to respect this. -Yes.
But also this one.
All of these were living, feeling, experiencing beings.
Okay, so let's look at these and show me,
is there a place in the brain where there's a lot of language going on?
What we do know about language is that most of the brain
is actually involved in some aspect of it.
-Yeah. -You really need the whole working cerebral cortex
to do what you and I do now.
Let's take a look at the non-human primate brain.
It's laid out pretty much the same way.
Look at that. But there's still so similar,
not just in physical shape, but even the responsibilities
or roles that the different places play.
Not only that, some of my early work was able to show that the connectivity
of these structures between each other is the same.
-Wow. -Or very, very similar. Obviously, this is larger,
-Yeah. -but the basic pattern of connections is the same.
[Michael] What do you think of the Cognitive Tradeoff hypothesis?
So, first of all, the systems that do memory in our brain
are not fundamentally different in their structure and their circuitry and so on.
-Yeah. -I think in the absence of language, we would
-probably be like chimpanzees, gorillas, orangutans, and so on. -Right.
But yet, they're able to perform really well at tasks
that seem to look like, "Did they take a picture or something?"
Exactly. Chimpanzees seem to do reasonably well at some of these tasks.
But we've traded off that ability in order to focus on language.
Because the memory systems we use in language
interface with each other in a way that's unusual.
Let me give you an example. Every book on my shelves,
no two sentences, probably, alike in any of these books.
An immense amount of detail!
And, having read a good part of almost all these books,
I couldn't tell you any of these sentences.
-No. -But if you ask me what's in this book,
what's its main ideas, I can probably give it to you.
-That's a remarkable capacity. -Yeah.
So what I'm suggesting as the tradeoff is sort of giving up the specific details--
to sacrifice it at one level gives it back to us at another level.
That's the power that we have gained from this.
Because of that power, we can get at information that no other species can get at,
both in our own experience, and in describing things in the world.
